XII. CHABRIAS

1. Chabrias, the Athenian. This man also was rated as one of the greatest of commanders and did many deeds worthy of record. But especially brilliant among these was his device in the battle which he fought near Thebes, when he came to che aid of the Boeotians. On that occasion, though 378 ac. the consummate leader Agesilaus felt sure of victory, since he had already put to flight the throngs of mercenaries, Chabrias checked him, forbade the phalanx, which was left³ unsupported, to abandon its position, and instructed the soldiers to receive the enemy’s onset with buckler on knee and lance advanced.
